channel.title: VCSA 6.5 on Emad Younis
channel.description: Recent content in VCSA 6.5 on Emad Younis

item.title: vCenter Server Appliance (VCSA) 6.5 Installer macOS Ovftool Error
item.description: Recently, some macOS Sierra users have had an issue with the VCSA 6.5 installer. At the â€œSet up appliance VMâ€ (step 5), the VCSA deployment and storage sizes are not available. The following error is received â€œA problem occurred while reading the OVF file.. Error: ovftool is not availableâ€. Let me start by saying this is not an issue with the VCSA 6.5 ISO or installer, it has to do with a change in Sierra. Also, before I go any further, Sierra is currently not supported with the VCSA 6.5 installer. Engineering is working to support Sierra in a future update. The supported system requirements for the VCSA installer are here. With that said, I want to shed more light on why this is happening and what options are available with Sierra.

item.title: vCenter Server Appliance (VCSA) 6.5 Installer Improvements
item.description: The vCenter Server Appliance (VCSA) 6.5 has significant new features and improvements mentioned here. One area of notice is the installer, which in this release not only has a new look and feel but other improvements. These improvements are not only visible from the ISO, but also during the deployment. The end result is a better experience throughout the VCSA deployment process. Letâ€™s jump in and take a closer look.

item.title: vCenter Server Appliance (VCSA) 6.5 What’s New Rundown
item.description: During VMworld Barcelona 2016, VMware announced vSphere 6.5. With lots of new features and updates, this is one of the biggest vSphere releases we have had in a while. Leading the charge is none other than the vCenter Server Appliance (VCSA). VMwareâ€™s direction for vCenter Server is the VCSA and itâ€™s quite evident from this release. The VCSA and its Windows counterpart remain on par when it comes to scalability. From an operational and feature perspective, the VCSA has advantages. This post is a quick rundown of the VCSA 6.5, Iâ€™ll go into more details in future blog posts. Time to take a look at whatâ€™s new and why migrate2vcsa you should ðŸ™‚
